Issues.Title: Incorrect behaviour of 'nav-right' for Bulma version above 0.5.3
Issues.Body:
When using Bulma version 0.5.x and previous versions, the behavior of `nav-right` is consistently correct. `nav-left` position the `nav-item` to the left `nav-right` position the `nav-item` to the right But when using Bulma version 0.6.x and later versions, the behavior of `nav-right` is incorrect. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Create a stylesheet definition: ``` ``` 2. Create `nav-menu` and `nav-item` ```
Home Right About Us RIght Contact Right
Home Left About Us Left Contact Left
``` 3. The behavior is correct for both `nav-right` and `nav-left`; 4. Change the stylesheet definition in step 1 from version `0.5.3` to version `0.6.0` » ... » `0.9.3`; 5. Then we got that the behavior for `nav-left` is correct but the behavior for `nav-right`is incorrect. ### Expected behavior `nav-right` should consistently position `nav-item` to the right ### Actual behavior `nav-right` incorrectly position `nav-item` to the left
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Incorrect behaviour of 'nav-right' for Bulma version above 0.5.3 " (#3483)

Issues.Title: .Control > .Input with has-icons-right and is-loading overlap
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **the Docs**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->
Loading spinner and icon overlap when an input wrapped in a control has both the `is-loading` class and the `has-icons-right` class with correct implementation.

<!-- This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** -->
This is about the Bulma **Docs** - This is where I found it as I messed about changing the HTML to understand the components better. This could also exist in the library though. I think the current version of bulma displayed on the docs could be older than the most recent release, based on some issue I was reading the other day about `disabled` vs `is-disabled` on anchor tags not displaying properly in the docs. 
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
My **browser** is: Firefox 95.0.2 (64bit)
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? I couldn't find a duplicate issue.

### Description
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59841145/148673741-d349bdac-5922-4910-a3f3-9fa56b2fdf3b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59841145/148673759-28a4f9e1-b5a3-4268-9fde-c6e6c7f4f43f.png)

<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->

### Steps to Reproduce
1. A `.control` div contains the classes `has-icons-right` and `is-loading`
2. A `.input` input has a child span/i tag with `is-right` and correct implementation.

<!--
1. First Step
2. Second Step
3. and so on...
-->

### Expected behavior
I would expect the `is-loading` spinner to be the only graphic displayed, as the loading indicates that a user has likely utilized the input field already. The indication of the loading behavior trumps the indication of the input icon.
<!-- What you expected to happen -->

### Actual behavior
Both the spinner and the icon were displayed at the same time, creating a confusing user experience.
<!-- What actually happened -->

I wonder if there is a way to add a style rule to apply `visibility:hidden` to the span icon whenever the parent `control` tag is loading.

There's probably a better way to go about it, but perhaps a naive implementation would look like:
```css
.control.has-icons-right.is-loading > .span.is-right > i {
  visibility: hidden
}
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".Control > .Input with has-icons-right and is-loading overlap" (#3468)

Issues.Title: @use instead of @import. Modules using * rather than scoping.
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is a ** improvement **.

<!-- Improvement? Explain how and why. -->

Use @use instead of @import to help facilitate the customisation and extension of bulma. This allows you to use @use to bring bulma into the site stylesheet. This provides better visibility of what is being imported. Bulma components are scoped as modules.

### Proposed solution

Replaces the @import with @use 

### Tradeoffs

- Minimal changes using "*" instead of scoping modules or specifically collecting variables that should/could be used in a site stylesheet e.g. initial_variables are likely to be overridden and derived_variables consumed in an expected derivative theme.
- Renamed _all to all_modulename instead of scoping 


### Testing Done

Local site testing. Conceptual start, discuss implementation and how this makes using Bulma better.


### Changelog updated?

No.

<!-- Thanks! -->

Issues.Title: $navbar-breakpoint seems to mess with the fixed navbar menu
Issues.Body:
<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma** (but it may also be lacking docs).

This is about the $navbar-breakpoint variable together with fixed and non-fixed menus.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.3]
My **browser** is: Chrome, mostly
This is a **SCSS** issue, but more about the variables
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate** because I searched, including the closed ones.

### Description

I am playing around with the navbar top menu. I have a short menu with only 4 small entries want to have a very small breakpoint for the menu (showing the full menu on most devices, and only collapsing to the hamburger menu on very narrow screens.

In my SCSS file I have defined `$navbar-breakpoint: 320px;` before including Bulma. 

Here part of my scss files (I also use bulmaswatch)

    /* Keep the menu visible on most but the smallest devices
    * @devdoc Must be applied before the bulma.sass is used, because this is used there */
    $navbar-breakpoint: 320px;

    /** Using Bulma CSS with a theme for Bulma */
    @import '../node_modules/bulmaswatch/slate/_variables.scss';

    @import '../node_modules/bulma/bulma.sass';
    @import '../node_modules/bulmaswatch/slate/_overrides.scss';

    /* Replayer-specific (smaller) section margins */
    @import 'replayer-section.scss';

    /* Player styles (to be used for the audio player) */
    @import 'replayer-player-styles.scss';

    /* Menu styles */
    @import 'replayer-navbar-styles.scss';

   .... some more specific styles

This works nice.

However I also wanted to use the fixed menu only on the larger screens (from desktop).  I encountered the `html.has-navbar-fixed-top-desktop` style, which seems to be undocumented. **This should be documented.**

**The real problem, however, is, that the aforementioned `$navbar-breakpoint: 320px;` seems to interfere with this `html.has-navbar-fixed-top-desktop`style, setting it now also to 320px, which seems wrong.**

It's wrong because it still says "desktop" which is far from 320px, and it should also not define the fixed-menu width.

In my case I explicitly want to have a full menu on most devices, but only a fixed menu on desktop sizes. As this currently is, I can not control both independently.

I have created custom scss code to address this, which I like to share, but I guess this should be properly addressed in the framwork itself.

**Probably all there is to do is to untangle the navbar breakt point from the desktop breakpoint.**


<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Define  $navbar-breakpoint: 320px;
2. Try to have a fixed menu only from the desktop width onwards

### Expected behavior

The navbar breakpoint should be as defined, AND the fixed menu should only kick in from desktop width

### Actual behavior

The fixed menu already kicks in at the navbar breakpoint
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "$navbar-breakpoint seems to mess with the fixed navbar menu" (#3459)

Issues.Title: docs - broken design at layout - container, hero and section ?
Issues.Body:
Hi,

while studying the docs in order to use it in a web app, i have found (_imho_) broken design pages:
- https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/container/
- https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/hero/
- https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/section/

These mentioned pages are shown equal in current google chrome and firefox (on windows).

Is this "broken design" wanted?

non-broken design:
If you load e.g. [doc footer ](https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/footer/), the doc itself in centered between ToC overall (left) and ToC current side itself (right). This looks as desired.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "docs - broken design at layout - container, hero and section ?" (#3456)
